                            had been lost from there; whether any person was with her; what she had
                            about her when she was lost; whether any one could recognize her. Why
                            should she make these inquiries? Unless, perhaps, she pretends--so great
                            is her assurance--that she herself is the same person that was formerly
                            lost when a little girl. But if she is alive, she is sixteen years old,
                            not older; whereas Thais is somewhat older than I am. She has sent to
                            press me earnestly to come. Either let her speak out what she wants, or
                            not be troublesome; I assuredly shall not come a third time
                                . Ho! there, ho! there!
                            Is any one here? It's I, Chremes.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: O most charming, dear creature!

p.#text: I said there was a design upon me.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Thais entreated you most earnestly to come again to-morrow.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'm going into the country.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Do, there's a dear sir.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I can not, I tell you.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Then stay here at our house till she comes back.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nothing less likely.

p.#text: Why, my dear Chremes?
Away to perdition with you!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
If you are so determined about it, pray do step over to the place where
                            she is.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll go there.

stage:
(Exit CHREMES with DORIAS, PYTHIAS goes into the
                                house.)
p.#text: Here, Dorias , show this person directly to the Captain's.

note.#text:
: It was the custom of parties who agreed to
                                join in a "symbola," or "club" or "picnic" entertainment, to give
                                their rings as pledges to the "rex convivii," or "getter up the
                                feast." Stakes were also deposited on making bets at races. See
                                Ovid's Art of Love, B. i., l. 168.

p.#text:
Yesterday some young fellows of us agreed
                            together at the 
                            that we were to go shares today in a club-entertainment. We gave Chaerea
                            charge of this matter; our rings were given as pledges; the place and
                            time arranged. The time has now gone by; at the place appointed there
                            was nothing ready. The fellow himself is nowhere to be met with; I
                            neither know what to say nor what to suppose. Now the rest have
                            commissioned me with his business, to look for him. I'll go see,
                            therefore, if he's at home. But who's this, I wonder, coming out of
                            Thais's? Is it he, or is it not? 'Tis the very man! What sort of being
                            is this? What kind of garb is this? What mischief is going on now? I can
                            not sufficiently wonder or conjecture. But, whatever it is, I should
                            like first at a distance to try and find out.

div2.stage: Enter CHAEREA from the house of Thais, in the EUNUCH'S dress.

p.stage: looking around, then aloud to himself.

l: I were now to be most happy; for, I fear,
My soul hath her content so absolute,
That not another comfort, like to this,

note.#text:
: There is a passage in the Othello of Shakspeare
                                extremely similar to this:

p.#text:
Is there any body
                            here? There's no one. Is there any one following me from there? There's
                            not a person. Now am I not at liberty to give vent to these raptures? O
                            supreme ! now assuredly
                            is the time for me to meet my death, when I can so well endure it; lest my life should
                            sully this ecstasy with some disaster. But is there now no inquisitive
                            person to be intruding upon me, to be following me wherever I do, to be
                            deafening me, worrying me to death, with asking questions; why thus
                            transported, or why so overjoyed, whither I'm going, whence I'm come,
                            where I got this garb, what is my object, whether I'm in my senses or
                            whether downright mad?

I'll accost him, and I'll do him the favor which I
                            see he's wishing for.  Chaerea, why are you
                            thus transported? What's the object of this garb? Why is it that you're
                            so overjoyed? What is the meaning of this? Are you quite right in your
                            senses? Why do you stare at me? What have you to say?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
O joyous day! O welcome, my friend! There's not one in all the world
                            whom I would rather wish to see at this moment that yourself.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Pray, do tell me what all this means.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
Nay rather, i'faith, I beg of you to listen to me. Do you know the
                            mistress whom my brother is so fond of?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I know her; I suppose you mean Thais?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: So far I recollect.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
To-day a certain damsel was presented to her. Why now should I extol or
                            commend her beauty to you, Antipho, since you yourself know how nice a
                            judge of beauty I am? I have been smitten by her.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Do you say so?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
If you saw her, I am sure you would say she's exquisite. What need of
                            many words? I fell in love with her. By good luck there was at our house
                            a certain Eunuch, whom my brother had purchased for Thais, and he had
                            not as yet been sent to her. On this occasion, Parmeno, our servant,
                            made a suggestion to me, which I adopted.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
Be quiet, and you shall hear the sooner; to change clothes with him, and
                            order myself to be taken there in his stead.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What, instead of the Eunuch?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: The fact.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: To receive what advantage, pray, from this plan?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
Do you ask? That I might see, hear, and be in company with her whom I
                            loved, Antipho. Is that a slight motive, or a poor reason? I was
                            presented to the woman. She, as soon as she received me, joyfully took
                            me home to her house and intrusted the damsel----

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: To whom? To you?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: To me.

p.#text: In perfect safety, at all events.

note.#text:
: The
                                "Gynecaea," or women's apartments, among the Greeks, always occupied
                                the interior part of the house, which was most distant from the
                                street, and there they were kept in great seclusion.

p.#text:
She gave orders that no male was to come near her, and commanded me not
                            to stir away from her; that I was to remain alone with her in the inner
                                apartments. Looking
                            bashfully on the ground, I nodded assent.
Poor fellow!

note.#text:
: These "noviciae" were young slaves
                                recently bought, and intended to be trained to the calling of a
                                Courtesan.

:
                                See the story of 
                                and Dana, the daughter of Acrisius, king of , in the Metamorphoses of
                                Ovid, B. iv., l. 610. Pictures of Venus and Adonis, and of
                                     and Ganymede,
                                are mentioned in the Menaechmi of Plautus; l. 144, and paintings on
                                the walls are also mentioned in the Mostellaria of Plautus, l. 821,
                                where Tranio tries to impose upon Theuropides by pretending to point
                                out a picture of a crow between two vultures.

: Donatus
                                remarks here that this was "a very proper piece of furniture for the
                                house of a Courtesan, giving an example of loose and mercenary Love,
                                calculated to excite wanton thoughts, and at the same time hinting
                                to the young lover that he must make his way to the bosom of his
                                mistress, like  to
                                Dana, in a shower of gold. Oh the avarice of
                                harlots!"

lemma.#text:
A
                                    poor creature of a mortal

note.#text:
: "Homuncio." He uses this word
                                the better to contrast his abject nature as a poor mortal with the
                                majesty of . St.
                                    Augustin refers to this
                                passage. The preceding line is said by Donatus to be a parody on a
                                passage by Ennius.

: As to the fans of
                                the ancients, see the Trinummus of Plautus, l. 252, and the Note to
                                the passage in Bohn's Translation. See also the Amours of , B. iii., El. 2, l.
                                38.

p.#text:
"I am going out," said she, "to dinner." She
                            took her maids with her; a few novices of girls remained, to be about her. These immediately made
                            preparations for her to bathe. I urged them to make haste. While
                            preparations were being made, the damsel sat in a room looking up at a
                            certain painting, in which was
                            represented how Jove is said once to have sent a golden shower into the
                            bosom of Dana. I myself began to look at it as well, and as he
                            had in former times played the like game, I felt extremely delighted
                            that a God should change himself into money, and slily come through the
                            tiles of another person's house, to deceive the fair one by means of a
                            shower. But what God was this? He who shakes the most lofty temples of
                            heaven with his thunders. Was I, a poor creature of a mortal, not to do the same? Certainly, I was to do
                            it, and without hesitation. While I was thinking over these matters with
                            myself, the damsel meantime was fetched away to bathe; she went, bathed,
                            and came back; after which they laid her on a couch. I stood waiting to
                            see if they gave me any orders. One came up, "Here, Dorus," said she,
                            "take this fan, and let her have a little air in this fashion, while we
                            are bathing; when we have bathed, if you like, you may bathe too." With
                            a demure air I took it.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p:
Really, I should very much have liked to see that impudent face of yours
                            just then, and what figure a great donkey like you made, holding a
                            fan!

l: "And how the young ladies all set up their clacks,
All the while an old woman was rubbing their backs."

note.#text:
: This line bears a
                                strong resemblance to two lines found in Anstey's new Bath Guide:

: This way of looking aside,
                                "limis," is mentioned in the Miles Gloriosus of Plautus, where
                                Milphidippa tells Acroteleutium to look at the Captain sideways,
                                "Aspicito limis," l. 1217; also in the Bacchides, l. 1131. Those
                                familiar with the works of Hogarth will readily call to mind the
                                picture of Bedlam in the Rake's Progress, where the young woman is
                                looking askance through her fan at the madman in his cell.

: This shows that
                                the fan was probably one made of thin boards, and not of
                                feathers.

p.#text:
Hardly had she said this, when all, in a
                            moment, betook themselves off: away they went to bathe, and chattered
                                aloud; just as the way is when masters are absent.
                            Meanwhile, sleep overtook the damsel; I slily looked askance
                            through the fan; this way : at the same
                            time I looked round in all directions, to see whether all was quite
                            safe. I saw that it was. I bolted the door.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Eh? What then, you simpleton?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I own I am.

note.#text:
: Colman has the following Note
                                here: "Short indeed, considering the number of incidents, which,
                                according to Chaerea's relation, are crowded into it. All the time
                                allowed for this adventure is the short space between the departure
                                of Thais and Thraso and the entrance of Chaerea; so that all this
                                variety of business of sleeping, bathing, ravishing, &c., is
                                dispatched during the two soliloquies of Antipho and Chaerea, and
                                the short Scene between Chremes and Pythias. The truth is, that a
                                very close adherence to the unities often drives the Poet into as
                                great absurdities as the perfect violation of them."

p.#text:
Was I to let slip the opportunity offered me, so excellent, so
                                short-lived, so
                            longed for, so unexpected. In that case, i'faith, I really should have
                            been the person I was pretending to be.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p:
Troth, you certainly are in the right; but, meantime, what has been
                            arranged about the club-entertainment?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: All's ready.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: You are a clever hand; but where? At your house?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
No, at Discus's, our
                            freedman.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: That's a long way off.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Then let's make so much the greater haste.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Change your dress.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
Where am I to change it? I'm at a loss; for at present I'm an exile from
                            home; I'm afraid of my brother, lest he should be in-doors: and then
                            again of my father, lest he should have returned from the country by
                            this.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Let's go to my house; there is the nearest place for you to change.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
You say right. Let's be off; besides, I want to take counsel with you
                            about this girl, by what means I may be able to secure the future
                            possession of her.

p.#text: Very well.

div2.stage: Enter DORIAS, with a casket in her hand.

note.#text:
: This
                                was probably because it was contrary to the laws of  for a Courtesan to appear
                                with gold or jewels in the street. Madame Dacier suggests another
                                reason, in which there is some force, although it is ridiculed by
                                Cooke. Thais may have supposed that the Captain, when irritated,
                                might not have scrupled to take them away from her. Indeed, nothing
                                would be more probable, than that he would be ready to take them by
                                way of security for the return of the slave, whom he had thus, to no
                                purpose, presented to her. In reference to the preceding line, we
                                may remark that it was not customary among the Greeks for females of
                                good character to appear at table with strangers.

p.#text:
So may the Gods bless me, but from what I
                            have seen, I'm terribly afraid that this mad fellow will be guilty of
                            some disturbance to-day or of some violence to Thais. For when this
                            young man, the brother of the damsel, arrived, she begged the Captain to
                            order him to be admitted; he immediately began to get into a passion,
                            and yet didn't dare refuse; Thais still insisted that he would invite
                            the man in. This she did for the sake of detaining him; because there
                            was no opportunity just then of telling him what she wanted to disclose
                            about her sister. He was invited in, and took his seat. Then she entered
                            into discourse with him. But the Captain, fancying it was a rival
                            brought before his very eyes, wanted in his turn to mortify her: "Hark
                            you, boy," said he, "go fetch Pamphila, that she may amuse us here." She
                            exclaimed, "At a banquet! Certainly not." The Captain still persisted to
                            a downright quarrel. Meanwhile my mistress secretly took off her golden
                                jewels, and gave
                            them to me to take away: this is a sign, I'm sure, that she'll betake
                            herself from there as soon as she possibly can.

note.#text:
: Donatus remarks that here the Poet artfully
                                finds a reason to bring Phaedria back again; as he at first with
                                equal art sent him out of the way, to give probability to those
                                incidents necessary to happen in his absence.

: "Extrem
                                line." There have been many suggestions offered for the
                                origin of this figurative expression. Some suggest that it alludes
                                to the last or lowest stage of the supposed ladder of love; others
                                that it refers to the first or elementary line traced by the
                                student, when beginning to learn the art of painting. It is however
                                more generally thought to be a metaphor taken from the chariotraces
                                in the Circus, where, in going round the turning-place, he who was
                                nearest was said "currere in prim line;" the
                                next, "in secund;" and so on to the last, who took the
                                widest range, and was said to run "in extrem
                                line."

p.#text:
While I was going into the
                            country, I began on the road, as it mostly happens when there is any
                            anxiety on the mind, to reflect with myself upon one thing after
                            another, and upon every thing in the worst light. What need of words?
                            While I was musing thus, inadvertently I passed my country-house. I had
                            already got some distance from it, when I perceived this; I returned
                            again, really feeling quite uneasy; when I came to the very turning that
                            leads to the house, I came to a stop, and began to reason with myself;
                            "What! must I stay here alone for two days without her? Well, and what
                            then? It's nothing at all. What? Nothing at all? Well now, if I haven;t
                            the privilege of touching her, am I not even to have that of seeing her?
                            If I may not do the one, at least I may the other. Surely to love at a
                                distance even, is better than nothing at all." I
                            purposely passed the house. But how's this, that Pythias is suddenly
                            hurrying out in such a fright?

div2.stage: Enter PYTHIAS and DORIAS in haste from the house of THAIS.

p.#text:
Where, wretch that I am, shall I find this wicked
                            and impious fellow? Or where look for him? That he should dare to commit
                            so audacious a crime as this! I'm ruined outright!
I dread what this may be.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Besides, too, the villain, after he had abused the girl, rent all the
                            poor thing's clothes, and tore her hair as well.

p.#text: Ha!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
If he were just now in my reach, how eagerly would I fly at that
                            villain's eyes with my nails!

p.#text:
Really I can't imagine what disturbance has
                            happened to us at home in my absence. I'll accost them.  What's the matter? Why in such haste? Or whom are
                            you looking for, Pythias?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Why, Phaedria, whom should I be looking for? Away with you, as you
                            deserve, with such fine presents of yours.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
What, do you ask? The Eunuch you gave us, what confusion he has caused.
                            He has ravished the girl whom the Captain made present of to my
                            mistress.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I'm ruined outright!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: You are drunk.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I wish that they were so, who wish ill to me.

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: Oh, prithee, my dear Pythias, what a monstrous thing this is!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: You are out of your senses. How could a Eunuch possibly do this?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
I know nothing about him: as to what he has done, the thing speaks for
                            itself. The girl is in tears; and when you ask her what's the matter,
                            she does not dare tell. But he, a precious fellow, is nowhere to be
                            seen. To my sorrow I suspect too, that when he took himself off he
                            carried something away from the house.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p:
I can not enough wonder, whither this varlet can possibly have betaken
                            himself to any distance from here; unless perhaps he has returned home
                            to our house.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Pray, go and see whether he is there.

p.stage:
Goes into the house of
                                LACHES.
p.#text: I'll let you know immediately.

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p:
Ruined outright! Prithee, my dear, I never did so much as hear of a deed
                            so abominable!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Why, faith, I had heard that they were extremely fond of the women, but
                            were incapable; unfortunately what has happened never came into my mind;
                            otherwise I should have shut him up somewhere, and not have intrusted
                            the girl to him.

div2.stage: Enter PHAEDRIA from the house of LACHES, with DORUS in CHAEREA'S clothes.

p.#text:
Come out, you villain! What, do you lag
                            behind, you runaway? Out with you, you sorry bargain!
Mercy, I do entreat you!

Oh, do look at that! How the villain distorts his face. What means your
                            coming back hither? Why this change of dress? What have you to say? If I
                            had delayed a moment, Pythias, I shouldn't have found him at home: he
                            had just prepared, in this fashion, for flight.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Have you caught the fellow, pray?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Caught him, why not?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: O well done!

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: Upon my faith that really is capital!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Where is he?

p.#text: Do you ask the question? Don't you see him?
See whom, pray?
This fellow, to be sure .

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: What person is this?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: The same that was brought to your house to-day.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Not one of our people has ever beheld this person with her eyes,
                            Phaedria.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Not beheld him?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Prithee, did you fancy that this was he who was brought to our
                            house?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Why, I had no other.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
O dear! this one really isn't to be compared with the other. He was of a
                            handsome and genteel appearance.

note.#text:
: It was
                                the custom to dress Eunuchs in party-colored clothes of bright hue.
                                Most probably it was from them that the "motley" descended to the
                                fools and buffoons of the Middle Ages.

p.#text:
He seemed so, just then, because he was decked out in party-colored
                                clothes: now he appears ugly,
                            for this reason--because he hasn't got them on.

note.#text:
: "Colore stellionino;"
                                probably having spots or freckles on his face like a "stellio" or
                                "lizard."

p.#text:
Prithee, do hold your tongue; as though indeed the difference was so
                            trifling. A young man was brought to our house to-day, whom, really,
                            Phaedria, you would have liked to look upon. This is a withered,
                            antiquated, lethargic, old fellow, with a speckled complexion.

Hah! What tale is this? You'll so befool me
                            that I sha'n't know what I bought.  How now,
                            sirrah, did I not buy you?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: You did buy me.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Bid him answer me in my turn.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Question him.

p.#text:
Did you come here to-day to our house?
                                 He says, no. But it was the
                            other one that came, about sixteen years of age; whom Parmeno brought
                            with him.

Well now, in the first place tell me this,
                            where did you get that dress that you have on? What, are you silent?
                            Monster of a fellow, are you not going to speak?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Chaerea came.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What, my brother?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: To-day.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: How long since?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Just now.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: With Parmeno.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Did you know him before?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: How did you know he was my brother?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Parmeno said he was. He gave me these clothes.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I'm undone!

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: He himself put on mine; afterward, they both went out together.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Now are you quite satisfied that I am sober, and that we have told you
                            no falsehood? Is it now sufficiently evident that the girl has been
                            ravished?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Avaunt, you beast, do you believe what he says?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: What is there to believe? The thing speaks for itself.

p.#text:
Step aside a little this way. Do you
                            hear?  A little further still. That
                            will do. Now tell me this once more; did Chaerea take your clothes off
                            you?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: And did he put them on?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: And was he brought here instead of you?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Great Jupiter! O wicked and audacious fellow!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Woe unto me! Now at last will you believe that we have been insulted in
                            a disgraceful manner?

p.#text:
It is no wonder that you believe what the fellow says.
                                 What I'm to do I know not.  Hark you, deny it all again. 
                            Can I not this day extract the truth from you? Did you really see my
                            brother Chaerea?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: No.

p.#text:
He can't be brought to confess without being punished, I see: follow me
                            this way. At one moment he affirms, at another denies.
                                 Ask pardon of me.

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Indeed, I do entreat you, Phaedria.

p.#text: Be off in-doors.

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Oh! oh!

p.#text:
How in any other fashion to get decently out of
                            this I don't know; for really it's all up with me.  Will you be trifling with me even
                            here, you knave?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
I'm as certain that this is the contrivance of Parmeno as that I'm
                            alive.

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: So it is, no doubt.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
I'faith, I'll find out a method to-day to be even with him. But now,
                            what do you think ought to be done, Dorias?

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: Do you mean with regard to this girl?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Yes; whether I ought to mention it or be silent?

lemma.#text: Have done a service to her

note.#text:
: Though some
                                would have "illi" here to refer to the damsel, and others again to
                                Phaedria, it is pretty clear that Madame Dacier is right in
                                suggesting that Thais is the person meant.

p.#text:
Upon my word, if you are prudent, you won't know what you do know,
                            either about the Eunuch or the girl's misfortune. By this method you'll
                            both rid yourself of all perplexity, and have done a service to
                                her. Say this only,
                            that Dorus has run away.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I'll do so.

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: But don't I see Chremes? Thais will be here just now.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p:
Because when I came away from there, a quarrel had just commenced
                            between them.

p.stage: DORIAS takes the casket into the house.
p.#text: Take in these golden trinkets; I shall learn from him what's the matter.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Heyday! upon my faith, I've been bamboozled: the wine that I've drunk
                            has got the upper hand. But, so long as I was reclining, how extremely
                            sober I did seem to myself to be; when I got up, neither feet nor senses
                            were quite equal to their duty.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Chremes!

p.#text:
Who's that? What, Pythias; dear me, how
                            much more charming you now seem to me than a short time since!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Troth now, you are much more merry, that's certain.

p.#text:
Upon my faith, it is a true saying, that "Venus grows cold without
                                 and Bacchus." But has
                            Thais got here long before me?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Has she already come away from the Captain's?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
A long time ago; an age since. There has been a most violent quarrel
                            between them.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Did she say nothing about you following her?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nothing at all; only, on going away, she gave me a nod.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Well now, wasn't that enough?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Why, I didn't know that she meant that, until the Captain gave me an
                            explanation, because I was dull of comprehension; for he bundled me out
                            of the house. But look, here she is; I wonder how it was I got here
                            before her.

p.#text:
I really do believe that he'll be here
                            presently, to force her away from me. Let him come; but if he touches
                            her with a single finger, that instant his eyes shall be torn out. I can
                            put up with his impertinences and his high-sounding words, as long as
                            they remain words: but if they are turned into realities, he shall get a
                            drubbing.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Thais, I've been here some time.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
O my dear Chremes, you are the very person I was wanting. Are you aware
                            that this quarrel took place on your account, and that the whole of this
                            affair, in fact, bore reference to yourself?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: To me? How so, pray?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
Because, while I've been doing my best to recover and restore your
                            sister to you, this and a great deal more like it I've had to put up
                            with.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: At home, at my house.

p.#text: Hah!

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
What's the matter? She has been brought up in a manner worthy of
                            yourself and of her.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
That which is the fact. Her I present to you, nor do I ask of you any
                            return for her.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Thanks are both felt and shall be returned in such way, Thais, as you
                            deserve.

note.#text:
: It was the custom with the ancients when they
                                exposed their children, to leave with them some pledge or token of
                                value, that they might afterward be recognized by means of them. The
                                catastrophes of the Curculio, the Rudens, and other Plays of
                                Plautus, are brought about by taking advantage of this circumstance.
                                The reasons for using these tokens will be stated in a future
                                Note.

p.#text:
But still, take care, Chremes, that you don't lose her, before you
                            receive her from me; for it is she, whom the Captain is now coming to
                            take away from me by force. Do you go, Pythias, and bring out of the
                            house the casket with the tokens.

Don't you see him,
                            Thais?
Where is it put?
In the clothes' chest. Tiresome creature, why do you delay?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
What a large body of troops the Captain is bringing with him against
                            you. Bless me!

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Prithee, are you frightened, my dear sir?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Get out with you. What, I frightened? There's not a man alive less
                            so.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Then now is the time to prove it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why, I wonder what sort of a man you take me to be.

note.title: Andria
note.#text:
: And therefore the
                                more unlikely to obtain redress from an Athenian tribunal. See the
                                    , l. 811, and the
                                Note to the passage.

p.#text:
Nay, and consider this too; the person that you have to deal with is a
                                foreigner; of less influence than you, less known,
                            and one that has fewer friends here.

I'm aware of that; but it's foolish to run the risk of what you are able
                            to avoid. I had rather we should prevent it, than, having received an
                            injury, avenge ourselves upon him. Do you go in and fasten the door,
                            while I run across hence to the Forum; I should like us to have the aid
                            of some legal adviser in this disturbance.
Stay.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Let me go, I'll be here presently.

p.stage:
Re-enter PYTHIAS from the house, with the
                                trinkets.
p.#text:
There's no occasion, Chremes. Only say that she is your sister, and that
                            you lost her when a little girl, and have now recognized her; then show
                            the tokens.
Here they are.

Take them. If he offers any
                            violence, summon the fellow to justice; do you understand me?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Take care and say this with presence of mind.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll take care.

stage:
They all go into
                                the house.
p.#text:
Gather up your cloak.  Undone! the very person whom
                            I've provided as a champion, wants one himself.

div2.stage: Enter THRASO, followed by GNATHO, SANGA, and other Attendants.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p:
Am I to submit, Gnatho, to such a glaring affront as this being put upon
                            me? I'd die sooner. Simalio, Donax, Syriscus, follow me! First, I'll
                            storm the house.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: I'll carry off the girl.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: I'll give her own self a mauling.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Very proper.

note.#text:
: We learn from the Fasti of Ovid, B.
                                iii., l. 117-8, that in early times the Roman armies carried bundles
                                or wisps of hay upon poles by way of standards. "A long pole used to
                                bear the elevated wisps, from which circumstance the manipular
                                soldier derives his name." It appears from this passage, and from
                                other authors, that to every troop of one hundred men a "manipulus"
                                or wisp of hay (so called from "manum implere," to "fill the hand,"
                                as being "a handful"), was assigned as a standard, and hence in time
                                the company itself obtained the name of "manipulus," and the
                                soldier, a member of it, was called "manipularis." The "centurio,"
                                or "leader of a hundred," was the commanding officer of the
                                "manipulus."

p.#text:
Advance hither to the main body,
                            Donax, with your crowbar; you, Simalio, to the left wing; you, Syriscus,
                            to the right. Bring up the rest; where's the centurion Sanga, and his maniple of rogues?
See, here he is.

note.#text:
: "Peniculo." This word meant a sponge
                                fastened to a stick, or the tail of a fox or an ox, which was used
                                as dusters or dish-clouts are at the present day for cleaning
                                tables, dishes, or even shoes. See the Menaechmi of Plautus, ver. 77
                                and 391.

p.#text: What, you booby, do you think of fighting with a dish-clout, to be bringing that here?

sp.speaker: SANGA
sp.p:
What, I? I knew the valor of the general, and the prowess of the
                            soldiers; and that this could not possibly go on without bloodshed; how
                            was I to wipe the wounds?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Where are the others?

sp.speaker: SANGA
sp.p:
Plague on you, what others? Sannio is the only one left on guard at
                            home.

stage: Takes his place behind the second rank.

note.#text:
: "Post principia." The Captain, with that
                                discretion which is the better part of valor, chooses the safest
                                place in his army. The "principes" originally fought in the van,
                                fronting the enemy, and behind them were the "hastati" and the
                                "triarii." In later times the "hastati" faced the enemy, and the
                                "principes" were placed in the middle, between them and the
                                "triarii;" but though no longer occupying the front place, they
                                still retained the name. Thraso, then, places himself behind the
                                middle line.

p.#text:
Do you draw up your men in battle order; I'll
                            be behind the second rank; from that position I'll give the word to all.

That's showing prudence; as soon as he has drawn
                            them up, he secures a retreat for himself.

stage: CHREMES and THAIS appear above at a window.

note.#text:
:
                                He attempts to defend his cowardice by the example of Pyrrhus, the
                                powerful antagonist of the Romans, and one of the greatest generals
                                of antiquity. He might have more correctly cited the example of
                                Xerxes, who, according to Justin, did occupy that position in his
                                army.

p.#text:
This is just the way
                            Pyrrhus used to proceed.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Do you see, Thais, what plan he is upon? Assuredly, that advice of mine
                            about closing the door was good.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
He who now seems to you to be a hero, is in reality a mere vaporer;
                            don't be alarmed.

p.#text: What seems best to you?

note.#text:
:
                                Although Vollbehr gives these words to Gnatho, yet, judging from the
                                context, and the words "ex occulto," and remembering that Thais and
                                Chremes are up at the window, there is the greatest probability that
                                these are really the words of Thais addressed aside to
                                Chremes.

p.#text:
I could very much like a sling to be given you just now, that you
                            might pelt them from here on the sly at a distance; they would be taking
                            to flight.

But look , I see Thais
                            there herself.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: How soon are we to fall to?

p.#text:
Hold ; it behooves a prudent person to
                            make trial of every thing before arms. How do you know but that she may
                            do what I bid her without compulsion?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p:
Ye Gods, by our trust in you, what a thing it is to be wise! I never
                            come near you but what I go away from you the wiser.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p:
Thais, in the first place, answer me this. When I presented you that
                            girl, did you not say that you would give yourself up to me alone for
                            some days to come?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Well, what then?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p:
Do you ask the question? You, who have been and brought your lover under
                            my very eyes? What business had you with him? With him, too, you
                            clandestinely betook yourself away from me.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: I chose to do so.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p:
Then give me back Pamphila; unless you had rather she were taken away by
                            force.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Give her back to you, or you lay hands upon her? Of all the----

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Ha! What are you about? Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: What do you mean? Am I not to touch my own?

note.#text:
: "Furcifer;" literally, "bearer of the
                                furca."

p.#text: Your own, indeed, you gallows-bird!

Have a care, if you please. You don't know
                            what kind of man you are abusing now.

Won't you be off from here? Do you know how
                            matters stand with you? If you cause any disturbance here to-day, I'll
                            make you remember the place, and day, and me too, for the rest of your
                            life.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: I pity you, who are making so great a man as this your enemy.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll break your head this instant if you are not off.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Do you really say so, puppy? Is it that you are at?

p.#text:
What fellow are you? What do you mean? What
                            business have you with her?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
I'll let you know: in the first place, I assert that she is a freeborn
                            woman.

p.#text: Ha!
A citizen of .

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Whew!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: My own sister.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Brazen face!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
Now, therefore, Captain, I give you warning; don't you use any violence
                            toward her. Thais, I'm going to Sophrona, the nurse, that I may bring
                            her here and show her these tokens.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: What! Are you to prevent me from touching what's my own?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I will prevent it, I tell you.

p.#text:
Do you hear him? He is convicting himself of
                            theft. Is not that enough for you?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Do you say the same, Thais?

p.stage:
She and CHREMES go away from the
                                window.
p.#text: Go, find some one to answer you.
What are we to do now?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p:
Why, go back again: she'll soon be with you, of her own accord, to
                            entreat forgiveness.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p:
Certainly, yes. I know the disposition of women: when you will, they
                            won't; when you won't, they set their hearts upon you of their own
                            inclination.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: You judge right.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Shall I dismiss the army then?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Whenever you like.

note.#text:
: Beaumont and Fletcher not improbably had this scene
                                in view in their picture of the mob regiment in Philaster. The
                                ragged regiment which Shakspeare places under the commend of
                                Falstaff was not very unlike it, nor that which owned the valiant
                                Bombastes Furioso as its Captain.

p.#text:
Sanga, as befits gallant soldiers, take care in your turn to
                            remember your homes and hearths.

sp.speaker: SANGA
sp.p: My thoughts have been for some time among the sauce-pans.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: You are a worthy fellow.

p.#text: You follow me this way.

div2.stage: Enter THAIS from her house, followed by PYTHIAS.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
What! do you persist, hussy, in talking ambiguously to me? "I do know;"
                            "I don't know;" "he has gone off;" "I have heard;" "I wasn't there."
                            Don't you mean to tell me plainly, whatever it is? The girl in tears,
                            with her garments torn, is mute; the Eunuch is off: for what reason?
                            What has happened? Won't you speak?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Wretch that I am, what am I to say to you? They declare that he was not
                            a Eunuch.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What was he then?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: That Chaerea.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What Chaerea?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: That stripling, the brother of Phaedria.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What's that you say, you hag?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: And I am satisfied of it.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Pray, what business had he at my house? What brought him there?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I don't know; unless, as I suppose, he was in love with Pamphila.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
Alas! to my confusion, unhappy woman that I am, I'm undone, if what you
                            tell me is true. Is it about this that the girl is crying?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
How say you, you arch-jade? Did I not warn you about this very thing,
                            when I was going away from here?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
What could I do? Just as you ordered, she was intrusted to his care
                            only.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
Hussy, I've been intrusting the sheep to the wolf. I'm quite ashamed to
                            have been imposed upon in this way. What sort of man was he?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Hush! hush! mistress, pray; we are all right. Here we have the very
                            man.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Why there, to the left. Don't you see?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: I see.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Order him to be seized as quickly as possible.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What can we do to him, simpleton?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
What do to him, do you ask? Pray, do look at him; if his face doesn't
                            seem an impudent one.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Besides, what effrontery he has.

div2.stage: Enter CHAEREA, in the EUNUCH'S dress, on the other side of the stage.

note.#text:
: Madame Decier here observes that Chaerea
                                assigns very natural reasons for not having changed his dress; in
                                which the art of Terence is evident, since the sequel of the Play
                                makes it absolutely necessary that Chaerea should appear again
                                before Thais in the habit which he wore while in the house.

p.#text:
At Antipho's,
                            both of them, father and mother, just as if on purpose, were at home, so
                            that I couldn't any way get in, but that they must have seen me. In the
                            mean time, while I was standing before the door, a certain acquaintance
                            of mine was coming full upon me. When I espied him, I took to my heels
                            as fast as I could down a narrow unfrequented alley; thence again to
                            another, and thence to another; thus have I been most dreadfully
                            harassed with running about, that no one might recognize me. But isn't
                            this Thais that I see? It is she. I'm at a stand. What shall I do? But
                            what need I care? What can she do to me?

Let's accost him. 
                            Good Mister Dorus, welcome; tell me, have you been running away?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Madam, I did so.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Are you quite pleased with it?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Do you fancy that you'll get off with impunity?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Forgive this one fault; if I'm ever guilty of another, then kill me.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Were you in fear of my severity?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: No? What then?

p.#text:
I was afraid of her, lest she might
                            be accusing me to you.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What had you done?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: A mere trifle.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Come now, a trifle, you impudent fellow. Does this appear a trifle to
                            you, to ravish a virgin, a citizen?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I took her for my fellow-servant.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Fellow-servant? I can hardly restrain myself from flying at his hair. A
                            miscreant! Even of his own free will he comes to make fun of us.

p.#text:
Won't you begone from here, you mad
                            woman?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Why so? Really, I do believe I should be something in this hang-dog's
                            debt, if I were to do so; especially as he owns that he is your
                            servant.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
We'll pass that by. Chaerea, you have behaved unworthily of yourself;
                            for if I am deserving in the highest degree of this affront, still it is
                            unbecoming of you to be guilty of it. And, upon my faith, I do not know
                            what method now to adopt about this girl: you have so confounded all my
                            plans, that I can not possibly return her to her friends in such a
                            manner as is befitting and as I had intended; in order that, by this
                            means, I might, Chaerea, do a real service to myself.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
But now, from henceforth, I hope, Thais, that there will be lasting
                            good-will between us. Many a time, from some affair of this kind and
                            from a bad beginning, great friendships have sprung up. What if some
                            Divinity has willed this?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
I'faith, for my own part I both take it in that view and wish to do
                            so.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
Yes, prithee, do so. Be sure of this one thing, that I did not do it for
                            the sake of affronting you, but in consequence of passion.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
I understand, and, i'faith, for that reason do I now the more readily
                            forgive you. I am not, Chaerea, of a disposition so ungentle, or so
                            inexperienced, as not to know what is the power of love.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
So may the Deities kindly bless me, Thais; I am now smitten with you as
                            well.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Then, i'faith, mistress, I foresee you must have a care of him.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I would not dare----

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I won't trust you at all in any thing.

p.#text: Do have done.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
Now I entreat you that you will be my assistant in this affair. I
                            intrust and commit myself to your care; I take you, Thais, as my
                            protectress; I implore you; I shall die if I don't have her for my
                            wife.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: But if your father should say any thing----

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Oh, he'll consent, I'm quite sure of that, if she is only a citizen.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
If you will wait a little, the brother himself of the young woman will
                            be here presently; he has gone to fetch the nurse, who brought her up
                            when a little child; you yourself, shall be present Chaerea, at his
                            recognition of her.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I certainly will stay.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p:
In the mean time, until he comes, would you prefer that we should wait
                            for him in the house, rather than here before the door?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Why yes, I should like it much.

p.#text: Prithee, what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Do you ask? Do you think of admitting him after this into your
                            house?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Trust my word for it, he'll be creating some new disturbance.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: O dear, prithee, do hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: You seem to me to be far from sensible of his assurance.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I'll not do any thing, Pythias.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Upon my faith, I don't believe you, Chaerea, except in case you are not
                            trusted.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Nay but, Pythias, do you be my keeper.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Upon my faith, I would neither venture to give any thing to you to keep,
                            nor to keep you myself: away with you!

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Most opportunely the brother himself is coming.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
I'faith, I'm undone. Prithee, let's be gone in-doors, Thais. I don't
                            want him to see me in the street with this dress on.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: For what reason, pray? Because you are ashamed?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Just so.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Just so? But the young woman----

p.stage: THAIS and CHAEREA go into the house.
p.#text:
Go first; I'll follow. You stay here, Pythias, that you may show Chremes
                            in.

Well! what now can suggest itself to my mind?
                            What, I wonder, in order that I may repay the favor to that villain who
                            palmed this fellow off upon us?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Really, do bestir yourself more quickly, nurse.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: I am bestirring.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: So I see; but you don't stir forward.

p.#text:
Have you yet shown the tokens to the
                            nurse?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: All of them.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Prithee, what does she say? Does she recognize them?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Yes, with a full recollection of them.

stage: CHREMES and SOPHRONA go into THAIS'S house.
p.#text:
Upon my faith, you do bring good news; for I really wish well to this
                            young woman. Go in-doors: my mistress has been for some time expecting
                            you at home. 
                            But look, yonder I espy that worthy fellow, Parmeno, coming: just see,
                            for heaven's sake, how leisurely he moves along. I hope I have it in my
                            power to torment him after my own fashion. I'll go in-doors, that I may
                            know for certain about the discovery; afterward I'll come out, and give
                            this villain a terrible fright.

stage: PYTHIAS enters from the house unperceived.

note.#text:
: He seems here
                                to reprehend the same practice against which Ovid warns his fair
                                readers, in his Art of Love, B. iii. l. 75. He says, "Do not first
                                take food at home," when about to go to an entertainment.
                                Westerhovius seems to think that "ligurio" means, not to "pick
                                daintily," but "to be fond of good eating;" and refers to the
                                Bacchides of Plautus as portraying courtesans of the "ligurient"
                                kind, and finds another specimen in Bacchis in: the
                                Heautontimorumenos.

p.#text:
I've just come back to see what Chaerea has
                            been doing here. If he has managed the affair with dexterity, ye Gods,
                            by our trust in you, how great and genuine applause will Parmeno obtain!
                            For not to mention that a passion, full of difficulty and expense, with
                            which he was smitten for a virgin, belonging to an extortionate
                            courtesan, I've found means of satisfying for him, without molestation,
                            without outlay, and without cost; then, this other point-that is really
                            a thing that I consider my crowning merit, to have found out the way by
                            which a young man may be enabled to learn the dispositions and manners
                            of courtesans, so that by knowing them betimes, he may detest them ever
                            after.  For
                            while they are out of doors, nothing seems more cleanly, nothing more
                            neat or more elegant; and when they dine with a gallant, they pick
                            daintily about: to see the filth, the dirtiness, the
                            neediness of these women; how sluttish they are when at home, and how
                            greedy after victuals; in what a fashion they devour the black bread
                            with yesterday's broth:--to know all this, is salvation to a young
                            man.<

Upon my faith, you villain,
                            I'll take vengeance upon you for these sayings and doings; so that you
                            sha'n't make sport of us with impunity.  O, by our trust in the Gods, what a disgraceful
                            action! O hapless young man! O wicked Parmeno, to have brought him
                            here!

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
I do pity him; and so that I mightn't see it, wretched creature that I
                            am, I hurried away out of doors. What a dreadful example they talk of
                            making him!

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
O Jupiter! What is this tumult? Am I then undone? I'll accost her.
                            What's all this, Pythias? What are you saying? An example made of
                            whom?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Do you ask the question, you most audacious fellow? You've proved the
                            ruin of the young man whom you brought hither for the Eunuch, while you
                            were trying to put a trick upon us.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: How so, or what has happened? Tell me.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
I'll tell you: that young woman who was to-day made a present to Thais,
                            are you aware that she is a citizen of this place, and that her brother
                            is a person of very high rank?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: I didn't know that.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
But so she has been discovered to be; he, unfortunate youth, has
                            ravished her. When the brother came to know of this being done, in a
                            most towering rage, he----

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Did what, pray?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: First, bound him in a shocking manner.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Bound him?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: And even though Thais entreated him that he wouldn't do so----

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: What is it you tell me?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Now he is threatening that he will also do that which is usually done to
                            ravishers; a thing that I never saw done, nor wish to.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: With what assurance does he dare perpetrate a crime so heinous?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: How "so heinous?"

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
Is it not most heinous? Who ever saw any one taken up as a ravisher in a
                            courtesan's house?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
But that you mayn't be ignorant of this, Pythias, I tell you, and give
                            you notice that he is my master's son.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: How! Prithee, is it he?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
Don't let Thais suffer any violence to be done to him. But why don't I
                            go in myself?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p:
Take care, Parmeno, what you are about, lest you both do him no good and
                            come to harm yourself; for it is their notion, that whatever has
                            happened, has originated in you.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
What then, wretch that I am, shall I do, or how resolve? But look, I see
                            the old gentleman returning from the country; shall I tell him or shall
                            I not? By my troth, I will tell him; although I am certain that a heavy
                            punishment is in readiness for me; but it's a matter of necessity, in
                            order that he may rescue him.

p.#text:
You are wise. I'm going in-doors; do you relate to him every thing
                            exactly as it happened.

note.#text:
: Donatus here
                                observes that the Poet introduces Laches, as he has Parmeno just
                                before, in a state of perfect tranquillity, that their sudden change
                                of feeling may be the more diverting to the Audience.

p.#text:
I have this advantage from my
                            country-house being so near at hand; no weariness, either of country or
                            of town, ever takes possession of me; when satiety begins to come on, I
                            change my locality. But is not that our Parmeno? Surely it is he. Whom
                            are you waiting for, Parmeno, before the door here?
Who is it  Oh, I'm glad that you have returned safe.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Whom are you waiting for?

p.#text:
I'm undone: my tongue cleaves to my mouth through
                            fright.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p:
Why, what is it you are trembling about? Is all quite right? Tell
                            me.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
Master, in the first place, I would have you persuaded of what is the
                            fact; whatever has happened in this affair has happened through no fault
                            of mine.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
Really you have reason to ask. I ought first to have told you the
                            circumstances. Phaedria purchased a certain Eunuch, to make a present of
                            to this woman here.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: To what woman?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: To Thais.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Bought? Good heavens, I'm undone! For how much?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Twenty minae.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Done for, quite.

p.#text: Then, Chaerea is in love with a certain music-girl here.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p:
How! What? In love? Does he know already what a courtesan means? Is he
                            come to town? One misfortune close upon another.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
Master, don't look so at me; he didn't do these things by my
                            encouragement.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p:
Leave off talking about yourself. If I live, you hang-dog, I'll---- But
                            first give me an account of it, whatever it is.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: He was taken to the house of Thais in place of the Eunuch.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: In place of the Eunuch?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
Such is the fact. They have since apprehended him in the house as a
                            ravisher, and bound him.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Death!

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Mark the assurance of courtesans.

sp.speaker: >LACH.
sp.p:
Is there any other calamity or misfortune besides, that you have not
                            told me of?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: That's all.

p.stage:
Runs into the house of
                            THAIS.
p.#text: Do I delay rushing in here?

note.#text:
: We
                                learn from Donatus that Menander was more explicit concerning the
                                resentment of Laches against Thais, on account of her having
                                corrupted Phaedria.

p.#text:
There's no doubt but that I shall have a
                            heavy punishment for this affair, only that I was obliged to act thus.
                            I'm glad of this, that some mischief will befall these women here
                            through my agency, for the old man has, for a long time, been on the
                            look-out for some occasion to do them a bad turn; at last he has
                            found it.

div2.stage: Enter PYTHIAS from the house of THAIS, laughing.

note.#text:
: She enjoyed it the more, knowing that the
                                old man had nothing to fear, as he had just heard the fiction which
                                she had imparted to Parmeno. Donatus observes that the terror of
                                Laches accounts for his sudden consent to the union of Chaerea with
                                Pamphila; for though he could not settle the matter any other way
                                with credit, he was glad to find that his son had made an unequal
                                match rather than endangered his life. Colman, however, observes
                                with considerable justice: "I think Chaerea apologizes still better
                                for this arrangement in the Scene with Thais at the opening of this
                                Act, where he says that he is confident of obtaining his father's
                                consent, provided Pamphila proves to be a citizen; and, indeed, the
                                match between them is rather a reparation of an injury done to her
                                than a degradation of himself."

p.#text:
Never, upon my faith, for a long
                            time past, has any thing happened to me that I could have better liked
                            to happen, than the old gentleman just now, full of his mistake, coming
                            into our house. I had the joke all to myself, as I knew what it was he feared.
Why, what's all this?
Now I'm come out to meet with Parmeno. But, prithee, where is he?
She's looking for me.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: And there he is, I see; I'll go up to him.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
What's the matter, simpleton? What do you mean? What are you laughing
                            about? Still going on?

p.#text:
I'm dying; I'm wretchedly tired with laughing
                            at you.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Why so?

p.#text:
Do you ask? Upon my faith, I never did see, nor shall see, a more silly
                            fellow. Oh dear, I can not well express what amusement you've afforded
                            in-doors. And still I formerly took you to be a clever and shrewd
                            person. Why, was there any need for you instantly to believe what I told
                            you? Or were you not content with the crime, which by your advice the
                            young man had been guilty of, without betraying the poor fellow to his
                            father as well? Why, what do you suppose his feelings must have been at
                            the moment when his father saw him clothed in that dress? Well, do you
                            now understand that you are done for?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
Hah! what is it you say, you hussy? Have you been telling me lies? What,
                            laughing still? Does it appear so delightful to you, you jade, to be
                            making fools of us?

p.#text: Very much so.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Yes, indeed, if you can do it with impunity.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Exactly so.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: By heavens, I'll repay you!

p.#text:
I believe you; but, perhaps, that which you are threatening, Parmeno,
                            will need a future day; you'll be trussed up directly, for rendering a
                            silly young man remarkable for disgraceful conduct, and then betraying
                            him to his father; they'll both be making an example of you.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: I'm done for!

lemma.#text:
In return for that present of
                                    yours

note.#text:
: By the present she means Chaerea in the disguise
                                of the Eunuch.

p.#text:
This reward has been found you in return for that present of
                                yours; I'm off.

note.#text:
: Which betrays itself by its own
                                squeaking.

p.#text:
Wretch that I am; just like a rat, this day
                            I've come to destruction through betrayal of myself.

Well now? With what hope, or what design, are
                            we come hither? What do you intend to do, Thraso?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: What, I? To surrender myself to Thais, and do what she bids me.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: What is it you say?

note.#text:
: He alludes to the story of Omphale,
                                Queen of , and
                                    . Being
                                violently in love with her, the hero laid aside his club and boar's
                                skin, and in the habit of a woman plied the spindle and distaff with
                                her maids. See a curious story of Omphale, , and , in the Fasti of , B. ii. l. 305. As to the
                                reappearance of Thraso here, Colman has the following remarks: "Thraso, says
                                Donatus, is brought back again in order to be admitted to some share
                                in the good graces of Thais, that he may not be made unhappy at the
                                end of the Play; but surely it is an essential part of the poetical
                                justice of Comedy to expose coxcombs to ridicule and to punish them,
                                though without any shocking severity, for their follies."

p.#text: Why any the less so, than  served Omphale.

note.#text:
: He doubtless alludes to the treatment of
                                     by Omphale;
                                and, according to ,
                                there was a story that Omphale used to beat him with her slipper or
                                sandal. On that article of dress, see the Notes to the Trinummus of
                                Plautus, 1. 252.

p.#text:
The precedent pleases me.  I only wish I may see
                            your head stroked down with a slipper; but her door makes a noise.

Confusion! Why, what mischiefs this? I never saw this person before;
                            why, I wonder, is he rushing out in such a hurry?

div2.stage: Enter CHAEREA from the house of THAIS, on the other side of the stage.

p.#text:
O fellow-townsmen, is there any one
                            alive more fortunate than me this day? Not any one, upon my faith: for
                            clearly in me have the Gods manifested all their power, on whom, thus
                            suddenly, so many blessings are bestowed.
Why is he thus overjoyed?

p.stage: seeing PARMENO, and running up to him.
p.#text:
O my dear Parmeno,
                            the contriver, the beginner, the perfecter of all my delights, do you
                            know what are my transports? Are you aware that my Pamphila has been
                            discovered to be a citizen?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: I have heard so.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Do you know that she is betrothed to me?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: So may the Gods bless me, happily done.

p.#text: Do you hear what he says?

lemma.#text:
To the patronage of my
                                    father

note.#text:
: It was the custom at  for strangers, such as
                                Thais was, to put themselves under the protection (in clientelam) of
                                some wealthy citizen, who, as their patron, was bound to protect
                                them against injury. An exactly parallel case to the present is
                                found in the Miles Gloriosus of Plautus, 1. 799, where the wealthy
                                Periplecomenus says, "Habeo, eccillam, meam clientam, meretricem
                                adolescentulam." "Why, look, I have one, a dependent of mine, a
                                courtesan, a very young woman."

p.#text:
And then, besides, I am delighted that my brother's mistress is secured
                            to him; the family is united. Thais has committed herself to the
                            patronage of my father; she has put herself under our
                            care and protection.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Thais, then, is wholly your brother's.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p:
Then this is another reason for us to rejoice, that the Captain will be
                            beaten out of doors.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
Wherever my brother is, do you take care that he hears this as soon as
                            possible.

p.stage:
Goes into the house of
                                LACHES.
p.#text: I'll go look for him at home.

Do you at all doubt, Gnatho, but that I
                            am now ruined everlastingly?
Without doubt, I do think so.

stage: Enter PHAEDRIA from the house of LACHES.
p.#text:
What am I to make mention of first, or
                            commend in especial? Him who gave me the advice to do so, or myself, who
                            ventured to undertake it? Or ought I to extol fortune, who has been my
                            guide, and has so opportunely crowded into a single day events so
                            numerous, so important; or my father's kindness and indulgence Oh
                            Jupiter, I entreat you, do preserve these blessings unto us!

Ye Gods, by our trust in you, what incredible
                            things has Parmeno just related to me! But where is my brother?
Here he is.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I'm overjoyed.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
I quite believe you. There is no one, brother, more worthy to be loved
